1.text: Get everything ready before you start cooking poached eggs.

2.text: Select a suitable pan for poaching.

4.text: If you'd like to help the eggs to set, add 5-10ml (1-2 teaspoons) of white vinegar to the water.

8.text: Turn down the gently boiling water to a simmer.

9.text: Spin the simmering water to cool down the water before you drop in the single egg.

10.text: Carefully lower or drop the egg into the center of the barely simmering whirlpool.

12.text: If poaching multiple eggs at once, do not spin the boiling water.

13.text: Remove the poached egg with a slotted spoon.

15.text: Use the steps outlined in the previous method.

16.text: Add the egg straight into the egg poacher.

17.text: Cook as outlined above, then pull out the whole egg poacher.

18.text: If you have access to a good kitchen store, consider purchasing a small silicon egg poacher cup or a set of silicon egg poachers (a set often comes with a pan with a clear lid).

19.text: Float the cup in the pan.

20.text: Bring to simmer and break the eggs into the cups.

21.text: Simmer with a covered pan for 8 minutes (at sea level).

22.text: Use a butter knife to separate the poached egg at edge of cup and invert the cup over toast.

24.text: In spite of what was said about serving immediately, as noted by Julia Child and other chefs like Michael Romano, it is possible to make poached eggs in advance for the busy cook with a crowd to feed.

25.text: Make the poached eggs as outlined above.

26.text: Simply plunge the poached eggs into plain icy water to chill.

27.text: Drop them into a pan of simmering, salted water for 20-30 seconds (and no more than one minute) and they're ready to serve immediately.

28.text: If the yolk breaks in the water, do not panic.

29.text: If the careful mixing doesn't work and the shape is not respectable, scoop out the egg (when cooked) with a slotted spoon.
